Electrochemical nitrate/nitric oxide (NO3 −/NO) reduction to ammonia (NH3) is an environmentally friendly and sustainable strategy that mitigates pollutants while synthesizing value-added products NH3. Despite the prevalence of transition metal-based catalysts, the exploration of inexpensive two-dimensional (2D) p-block materials is needed in NH3 synthesis. Based on density functional theory calculations, we proposed an InSe monolayer with single Se vacancy as an outstanding catalyst for NO3RR and NORR. The catalyst exhibits exceptional catalytic performance, characterized by a low limiting potential comparable to that of most transition metal-based catalysts, and efficaciously suppresses the formation of competitive by-products. Successful adsorption and activation of NO3 − and NO molecules are achieved, attributed to the charge rearrangement around the vacancy. The electronic structure analysis reveals that the enhancement of activity stems from the upward shift of the p-band center of unsaturated indium atoms. This work heralds a novel avenue for designing pure 2D p-block NH3 synthesis catalysts and sheds light on a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism at the electronic level. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical NO3 −/NO reduction p-block 2D InSe monolayer vacancy engineering first principles calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is the essential compound of chemical products and raw material for the synthesis of nitrogen-based fertilizers, such as urea and ammonium nitrate [1,2]. In recent years, NH3 has also been recognized as a promising clean energy carrier and storage medium. Conventional industrial production of NH3 primarily involves the Haber–Bosch (H–B) process, where N2 and H2 react at elevated temperatures (around 500 °C) and high pressure (175 bar) [3]. However, the H–B process confronts environmental challenges as it heavily relies on H2 production from fossil fuel combustion, resulting in 1.4 % of global CO2 emissions. Among the diverse alternative strategies, the electrocatalytic conversion of NO x (x = 1, 2, 3) to NH3 is admitted as a green and sustainable solution [4-8]. On the one hand, with the excessive use of agricultural fertilizers and accelerated industrialization, NO x species have emerged as predominant pollutants in the wastewater and atmosphere. In particular, elevated nitrate (NO3 −) concentrations have profound consequences for the global nitrogen cycle and ecological balance, leading to the generation of acid rain and photochemical smog, which have substantially endangered the quality of social life and directly threaten human health. The electrochemical reduction of NO x to NH3 involves only hydrogen proton pairs derived from generated electricity by renewable energy, like solar and wind energy. On the other hand, the NH3 produced by electrochemical NO x species is characterized by a dramatic decline in energy consumption per unit mass of absolute substance, which can be attributed to the lower dissociation energy of NO x than that of the N2 molecule (941 KJ/mol) [8-12]. Consequently, beyond N2, nitrogen oxides stand as an alternative nitrogen source capable of environmentally friendly and energy-saving NH3 production, thereby contributing to a more sustainable nitrogen cycle. Since nitrite (NO2 −) is unstable in acidic conditions, most of the previous studies have been focused on electrochemical nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) or nitric oxide reduction reaction (NORR) to NH3 [13-16]. Despite significant breakthroughs in experiments and theoretical simulations, there remain ample opportunities for boosting the catalytic activity and selectivity of NO x RR catalysts [17-21]. For large-scale applications, it is imperative to design and tailor efficient and green catalysts for NH3 production. The electrons in the d shells play a crucial role in facilitating the injection of charges into the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of NO3 − and NO, thereby activating the NO bonds and augmenting the catalytic performance. As a result, transition metals (TMs) with highly occupied and unoccupied d orbitals as active sites, have consistently been the research hotspots on electrocatalysis, including pure metals [22-24], alloys [25,26], single atoms catalysts (SACs) [27-32], double atoms catalysts (DACs) [33-40], and single-atom alloy catalysts (SAACs) [41,42]. Regrettably, the open d-orbitals of TMs would tend to accept electrons from H atoms, favoring the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), undermining the reduction of NO x and ultimately curtailing the Faraday efficiency. Distinct from TMs, p-block metals with closed d shells, characterized by a d 10 electronic configuration, are typically regarded catalytically inferior and have rarely been investigated. Intriguingly, p-block metals, regulated by defect, alloys, doping, and heterojunction engineering, have been demonstrated as promising candidates with enhanced activity for electrocatalytic reactions [43-47]. For instance, Jiao et al. successfully synthesized a p-block SAC composed of antimony-nitrogen-carbon (SbNC), exhibiting exceptional stability, activity, and selectivity in oxygen reduction reactions [43]. Notably, the power density of Sb-SAC for Zn-air batteries surpasses that of most TM-based SACs, including the commonly employed commercial electrodes Pt-C. Recently, Du et al. proposed that the pure p-block In3Sn alloy exhibits outstanding performance in NO3RR with a completely downhill free energy change [44]. Moreover, the application of vacancy engineering holds promise in augmenting the Faraday efficiency and current density of electrocatalytic NO3RR [45]. Thus, it should be feasible to attain selective NO x RR for NH3 production through the development of novel 2D p-block materials. Inspired by recent experiment works, the incorporation of yttrium into 2D InSe semiconductors for field-effect transistors (FETs) has exhibited performance levels surpassing state-of-the-art silicon FETs [48]. Ag-doped InSe nanosheets with Se vacancies manifested notably high current density in the electro-reduction of CO2 to ethanol [49]. Very recently, Wong et al. discovered that 2D InSe monolayer (ML) exhibits ultra-high plasticity, showcasing substantial promise for the development and design of high-performance inorganic plastic semiconductors [50]. Considering the high electron mobility of InSe [51] and the fact that Se defects can be synthesized experimentally, the catalytic behavior of pristine and defective InSe MLs for NO3RR and NORR was systematically explored with the first-principles calculations. We found that the defective InSe ML is an excellent NO3RR and NORR catalyst with a limiting potential of −0.51 V, i.e., corresponding to the reaction temperature under ambient conditions. Moreover, it effectively inhibits the formation of competitive by-products, including H2, N2, N2O, NO, and NO2. Charge density difference and Bader charge analysis revealed substantial charge accumulation at the Se-vacancy. The analysis at the electronic level unraveled that the stable adsorption and accelerated activation of NO3 − and NO molecules on the defective InSe ML are derived from the upward shift of the p-band center of unsaturated indium atoms. Hence, our work validates defect engineering as a promising strategy for boosting NO3RR/NORR on the InSe ML. 2 Computational methods All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed in the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [52]. Electron-ion interactions were described by the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [53], the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to address exchange-correlation interactions [54]. A cutoff energy of 520 eV was set. The convergence criteria for energy and force are 1.0 × 10−5 eV and 0.03 eV/Å, respectively. The first Brillouin zones were sampled with 3 × 3 × 1 and 6 × 6 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grids for structure optimization and electronic structure calculations, respectively. To prevent artificial interactions between neighboring periodic cells, a vacuum space of 20 Å was introduced in the z-direction. For precise evaluation of small molecule adsorption, van der Waals D3 (DFT-D3) correction was considered [55]. To test the thermodynamic stability of 2D InSe with Se vacancy, ab initio molecules dynamic (AIMD) simulations were conducted within the NVT ensemble at 500 K. To evaluate the solvent effects on catalytic activity, the Poisson–Boltzmann implicit solvation model in VASPsol is employed, with a dielectric constant of 80.0 for water. The adsorption energy of NO3 − can be obtained by: E ads = E * N O 3 + 1 2 E H 2 ( g ) − E * − E HN O 3 ( g ) , where E * N O 3 and E * is the total energy of with and without NO3 − adsorption, respectively. E H 2 ( g ) and E HN O 3 ( g ) is the energy of free H2 and HNO3 molecule, respectively. Detailed calculations process can be found in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pristine InSe ML structure The top and side views of the 2D InSe ML are illustrated in Fig. 1 . The unit cell is outlined by a black dashed rhombic, and the Se vacancy's position is marked by a red dashed circle. As can be seen from the side view, the InSe ML consists of four atomic layers, with two indium layers in the middle and selenium layers on both sides, forming a Se-In-In-Se sequence that constructs a double honeycomb structure when two In/Se atoms overlap along the z direction. Each Se atom is bonded to three In atoms, while each In atom is coordinated with three Se atoms and one In atom. 3.2 Stability of vacancy The vacancy formation energy (E f) serves as a crucial parameter for evaluating the relative stability of materials with vacancies in thermodynamic equilibrium. Typically, the formation of vacancy is intricately linked to the synthesis environment, while the formation energy depends on the chemical potentials of the constituent elements. To introduce the point vacancy, a 4 × 4 × 1 supercell was constructed. As shown in Figs. 2 and S1, we considered five possible vacancy configurations, namely mono-selenium vacancy (VSe), di-selenium vacancy (VSe2), mono-indium vacancy (VIn), di-indium vacancy (VIn2), indium-selenium vacancy pair (VInSe). The E f is defined by the formula: E f = E d e f − E p r i + Δ n i ∑ i = 1 μ , where the E def and E pri represents the total energy of the defective and pristine InSe MLs, respectively. The variable Δn and μ denotes the change in the number of vacancy atoms and the chemical potential, respectively. The calculated results are depicted in Fig. 2(f), the lower boundary, corresponding to the In-rich condition, is given by the chemical potential of Se ( μ Se ) = ( E pri − 2 × μ In ) / 2 , where the chemical potential of In ( μ In ) is the energy per atom in the indium bulk. On the contrary, the upper boundary corresponds to the Se-rich condition, the μ Se is equal to the energy per atom in the selenium bulk, while μ In = ( E pri − 2 × μ Se ) / 2 . Consequently, the stability of InSe ML ranges from −1.1 eV < μ Se < 0 eV, which is consistent with the range of variation of the μ Se of MoSe2 [56]. As expected, the single Se vacancy under In-rich conditions is the most favorable configuration with the lowest E f of 1.24 eV. Notably, the value aligns with previously reported results of VS-MoS2 and VSe-MoSe2 [56,57]. To further assess the thermodynamic stability of the InSe ML with single Se vacancy (VSe-InSe), AIMD simulations were conducted at 500 K for 10 ps. As shown in Fig. S2, both the energy and temperature oscillate within a small and reasonable range. The above tests affirmed the high thermodynamic stability and experimental synthesis feasibility of VSe-InSe MLs. Therefore, the following discussion will focus predominantly on individual Se defect. 3.3 Reduction of NO3 − and NO The effective adsorption of NO3 −/NO is a paramount prerequisite for the subsequent hydrogenation process. Initially, we explored the adsorption of NO3 − on both clean and defective InSe MLs. In light of our calculations, nitrate fails to achieve stable adsorption on a pristine InSe ML, as evidenced by the distance between one oxygen atom of NO3 − and the substrate greater than 3 Å (see Fig. S3), indicating relatively limited nitrate catalytic activity. However, the removal of the Se atom exposes the indium active sites, inducing the activation of NO3 −. The same adsorption configurations of NO3 − were considered on VSe-InSe ML, where the configuration of three oxygen atoms interacting with three exposed indium atoms proved to be the most favorable [see Fig. 3 (a)]. The calculated adsorption energy is −0.59 eV, and the NO bond lengths of NO3 − are significantly stretched to 1.34 Å compared to 1.26 Å on perfect InSe ML. In addition, substantial charge transfer (1.35 e) from the unsaturated indium sites to NO3 − is visible in charge density difference (CDD) maps of Fig. 3(b) and (c), indicating that nitrate on VSe-InSe ML is steadily adsorbed and the bonds inside the nitrate itself are significantly weakened. Vacancy concentration may affect the stability and NO3 − adsorption, the formation energy of Vse and the adsorption energy of nitrate were compared in different supercells. As shown in Table S1, supercell size has little effect on the E f, and the difference in E ads is negligible between 4 × 4 × 1 and 5 × 5 × 1 supercells, the smaller one is sufficient to explore the intrinsic mechanism of NO3RR. From the perspective of electronic structure to reveal the impact of Se vacancies on catalytic activity, the density of states (DOS) and CDD plots of the pure and defective InSe MLs were calculated. As illustrated in Fig. S4 for the CDD maps, charge redistribution occurs around the vacancy, in contrast to the observation in the perfect case. The Bader charge analysis stated that there is 0.57 e accumulation at the vacancy. The partial density of states (PDOS) analysis in Fig. 4 (a) and (b) reveals that pristine InSe ML exhibits a noticeable band gap, while the presence of VSe induces defect states, reducing the band gap and enhancing the conductivity, which is conducive to the whole catalytic reaction. For the clean InSe ML, the valence band maximum (VBM) is dominated by orbitals of both In and Se atoms, while the conduction band minimum (CBM) is mainly dominated by Se atoms. Noteworthy, for the case of VSe-InSe, the VBM and CBM are prevailed by orbitals of the three unsaturated In atoms in proximity to the vacancy. The charge accumulation around In atoms [see Fig. 4(c) and (d)] promotes electron transfer and strengthens the adsorption of NO3 −. Vacancies necessarily affect the p-orbital center position ( ε p ) of the active site. Analogous to the effects of the d-band center on the transition metal catalysts [58], in general as well as reported, the closer the ε p is to the Fermi level, the stronger the adsorption of reactants on catalysts [59]. Specifically, for the pure InSe ML, the value of ε p is −1.04 eV, far away from the Femi level. While for the defective case, ε p is closer to the Fermi level with a value of −0.35 eV, indicating boosted catalytic activity. The electron occupation of antibonding states in the VSe-InSe ML is diminished, resulting in stronger adsorption of NO3 −, i.e., a relatively more negative adsorption energy. So far, vacancy engineering effectively regulated the electronic structure and upshifted the p-band center of the active sites, thereby enhancing the adsorption and activation of NO3 −, and facilitating the catalytic activity of the NO3RR. The reduction of NO3 − is a complicated process involving a variety of reaction intermediates and the by-products H2, NO, and NO2. All possible reaction pathways and intermediates are shown in Fig. 5 (a). Previous researches overwhelmingly indicate that the nitrogen atom in the *NO intermediate favors adsorption on surfaces over the oxygen atom [22,23,27,42]. Therefore, the reaction pathway is broadly categorized into partial deoxygenation (*NHO path) and continuous hydrogenation after total deoxygenation (*NOH path). Contrastingly, *ON and *ONH intermediates are favored in our system. The free energy diagram and the optimal intermediate structures on VSe-InSe for NO3RR are presented in Fig. 5(b) and (d). Initially, NO3 − adsorbs onto the unsaturated In site, with a slight increase in free energy by 0.002 eV. Afterward, the *NO3 specie is attacked by two hydrogen proton pairs (H+ + e−) to form the *NO2 intermediate, and an H2O molecule is released, whose free energy drops dramatically by −1.59 eV. This process proceeds with the next hydrogenation of *NO2, leading to the formation of either *NO or *ON intermediates, potentially with NO2 and NO gases as by-products. However, the desorption of NO2 and NO gases presents a challenge as the energy barrier is 1.01 eV and 0.76 eV, respectively. Proton pairs then selectively attack either the bonded O or the distal N atom, forming *OHN or *ONH intermediates, the latter being thermodynamically more favorable, evidenced by a free energy decrease of 0.85 eV. Next, the protonation of *ONH yields two more intermediates, *OHNH or *ONH2, with free energy changes of 0.80 eV and 0.33 eV, respectively. The *ONH2 intermediate is attacked by a proton-electron pair, resulting in NH3 being released, while *O continues to adsorb onto the unsaturated In site. In the subsequent hydrogenation steps (*O → *OH → *OH2), the Gibbs free energy change is 0.51 eV and 0.28 eV, respectively. During the whole process, the potential determination step (PDS) of VSe-InSe for the NO3 − reduction to NH3 is from *O hydrogenation to *OH step with a maximum energy uphill of 0.51 eV, which is comparable to recently reported transition metal-based catalysts [41,60-62]. Ideally, the nitrate electrochemical reduction pathway is identified as *NO3 → *NO2 → *ON → *ONH → *ONH2 → *O+NH3 → *OH → *OH2 → *+H2O. The geometry structures of the corresponding intermediate are presented in Fig. 5(d). Given that electrochemical NO3RR occurs in aqueous solutions, we utilized an implicit solvation model in VASPsol (with a dielectric constant of 80.0 for water) to explore the solvent's impact on the catalytic activity on VSe-InSe ML. As displayed in Fig. S5, the solvation effect minimally affects the free energy of most intermediates. Notably, the PDS remains unchanged, while the limiting potential is reduced after considering the solvation effect. Hence, the results suggest that the solvent effect has a negligible effect on the overall catalytic performance of NO3RR on VSe-InSe ML. The catalytic behavior of pristine and defective InSe MLs for the direct electrochemical synthesis of NO to NH3 was also explored. For the pure InSe ML, four potential adsorption patterns were considered, as shown in Fig. S6. Similar to NO3 −, the distance between the O or N atom of NO and the substrate is larger than 3 Å, indicating a relatively weak adsorption. Interestingly, NO can be adsorbed on V-InSe, in which NO lying flat in the defect position is the most favorable configuration, the corresponding geometry and energy difference are summarized in Fig. S6. The adsorption free energy of −0.76 eV and the significant elongation of the NO bond from 1.15 Å in the free gas to 1.31 Å, both indicate a considerable activation of the NO molecule on VSe-InSe. For NO molecule, the favorable adsorption configuration is consistent with that of the *ON intermediate in the NO3RR, and the subsequent hydrogenation process also follows the pathway, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The PDS of VSe-InSe for the NO reduction to NH3 is again from *O → *OH step with a maximum energy uphill of 0.51 eV. In addition to eminent NH3 catalytic performance, a prospective NORR catalyst should possess high NH3 selectivity to inhibit competing reactions that lead to the formation of side-products. During NORR process, N2 and N2O are the possible by-products at high NO coverages. In previous reports, *OONN and *NNOO have been identified as potential intermediates when *NO dimers co-adsorbed on the catalyst, along the *NNOO pathway, the products of N2O and N2 yields, while in the *OONN pathway, N2O is formed. Here, *OONN intermediate is more favorable, with a 1.60 eV drop in free energy, as shown in Fig. 5(c). And the free energy of the first hydrogenation from *OONN to *OOHNN rises by 0.87 eV, indicating that the N2O and N2 products are restrained. 3.4 Suppression of HER The major competitive reaction of NO3RR/NORR is the hydrogen evolution reaction, and if the active sites are occupied by hydrogen, the catalytic activity would be significantly reduced, leading to a loss of Faraday efficiency. The HER activity of catalysts is typically assessed by the Gibbs free energy of proton ( Δ G * H ), where a value closer to zero implies excellent HER performance. Therefore, for superior NO3RR and NORR catalysts, the Gibbs free energy of nitrate ( Δ G * N O 3 ) or nitric oxide ( Δ G * NO ) must be lower than that of Δ G * H to suppress HER. The calculated Δ G * H of all potential proton adsorption sites over the catalysts VSe-InSe are illustrated in Fig. 6 (a). It can be seen that the V-B site is the most favorable adsorption site with the lowest Δ G * H . Evidently, the Δ G * H value of 0.81 eV is much larger than the 0.09 eV of the commercial Pt catalyst, suggesting VSe-InSe is poor for HER. Moreover, Δ G * N O 3 (0.002 eV) and Δ G * NO (−0.76 eV) are more negative than Δ G * H (0.81 eV). These results reveal that VSe-InSe demonstrates outstanding NO3RR and NORR catalytic activity, and prevents the occurrence of HER. 4 Conclusions In summary, we carried out a systematic exploration into the possibility of both pristine and defective 2D InSe MLs toward NO3RR and NORR. It was found that individual Se vacancy on the surface is the most favorable defect configuration due to its low formation energy. In comparison to the pure InSe ML, the VSe-InSe ML can steadily adsorb NO3 − and NO, which is attributed to the charge accumulation at the Se vacancy. The density of states analysis reveals that the presence of Se vacancy introduces defective states within the band gap of pristine material, and boosts conductivity, thereby promoting the whole electrochemical process. Significantly, we identify that VSe-InSe ML is an excellent NO3RR and NORR catalyst with a low limiting potential of −0.51 V, indicating that it works under ambient conditions and effectively inhibits the competitive by-products. Given the experimental feasibility of synthesizing Se vacancy in InSe, this work presents a potential avenue for the design of NO3RR/NORR catalysts under environmental conditions using low-cost 2D p-block monolayers and could open the door for NH3 electrosynthesis. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical nitrate/nitric oxide (NO3 −/NO) reduction to ammonia (NH3) is an environmentally friendly and sustainable strategy that mitigates pollutants while synthesizing value-added products NH3. Despite the prevalence of transition metal-based catalysts, the exploration of inexpensive two-dimensional (2D) p-block materials is needed in NH3 synthesis. Based on density functional theory calculations, we proposed an InSe monolayer with single Se vacancy as an outstanding catalyst for NO3RR and NORR. The catalyst exhibits exceptional catalytic performance, characterized by a low limiting potential comparable to that of most transition metal-based catalysts, and efficaciously suppresses the formation of competitive by-products. Successful adsorption and activation of NO3 − and NO molecules are achieved, attributed to the charge rearrangement around the vacancy. The electronic structure analysis reveals that the enhancement of activity stems from the upward shift of the p-band center of unsaturated indium atoms. This work heralds a novel avenue for designing pure 2D p-block NH3 synthesis catalysts and sheds light on a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism at the electronic level.
